Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Full-Field Digital Stress Gradient Sensor for Failure Characterization of Transparent Structural Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a full-field, non-contact, optical technique to quantify angular deflections of light rays caused by non-uniform stress fields in optically transparent solids. The method exploits the elasto-optic effect in concurrence with the digital image correlation methodology to extract orthogonal stress gradients in transparent solids. The feasibility of the method to study failure behavior of solids under quasi-static and high strain rate loading conditions will be demonstrated using visible and near infrared radiation. The successful development of this new method will provide a powerful, complementary measurement tool for experimental solid mechanics.

Optical transparency is a common characteristic of solids used in many engineering applications including electronic displays, automotive windshields, aircraft windows and canopies, hurricane resistant windows, and helmet visors. This research contributes towards understanding failure mechanics of such materials under quasi-static and stress wave loading conditions. Education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary areas of optical metrology and mechanical characterization of structural materials is integral to this research. Findings from this research will be displayed during annual undergraduate and graduate recruitment events to attract K-12 and underrepresented students to engineering. The findings will also be integrated into graduate courses taught by the PI and disseminated through archival journals and conference publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research has developed two variants of a vision-based, remote sensing, optical methodology called Digital Gradient Sensing to precisely measure very small angular deflections (as small as a thousandth of a degree) of light rays caused by non-uniform mechanical stresses in transparent and reflective materials. The method quantifies changes in the lateral thickness and/or density (and hence refractive index) of materials due to mechanical stresses.  The feasibility of the method to study mechanical failure behavior of solids under slow and high rate loading conditions (such as impact) has been demonstrated using visible and infrared radiations. 

The DGS method has shown promise on multiple fronts: (a) To perform optical metrology of thin reflective objects; e.g., silicon wafer used in the electronic chip industry, (b) To perform non-destructive evaluation of inhomogeneties and defects in transparent sheets, (c) To quantify deformations in extremely soft gels as well as extremely stiff ceramics such as glass. 

The research has resulted in seven refereed articles in archival journals with graduate student mentees of the PI has the lead authors.  Over ten conference articles have been published and an equal number of presentations have been made at national and international conferences.  A patent application has also been submitted for approval.

Two graduate students have completed their thesis research and obtained their graduate degrees.  Two additional graduate students with overlapping interests and one undergraduate student (from the underrepresented category in engineering) have contributed to this project.  All these students have received hands-on training in various aspects of experimental mechanics, optical metrology, mechanics of materials.  The PI has been able to introduce highlights of the research in a graduate course on "experimental mechanics" in the mechanical engineering department at Auburn U.  The student participants and the PI have contributed to research activities across the college and the university via participation in "annual elements of mechanical engineering conference", and "engineering research show case" poster competitions conducted by the Council of Engineering Graduate Students .
